title: Mayor dragged through streets by people angry at state of roads
text:
The mayor of Las Margaritas is dragged through the streets (Picture: CEN)

Furious farmers stormed a council meeting, seized the mayor and dragged him through the town tied to the back of a pick-up truck.

Eyewitnesses described seeing mayor Jorge Luis Escandon attacked after being confronted in southern Mexico.

Dozens of members of the Tojolabal indigenous community, armed with clubs, broke into the building in the town of Las Margaritas in the state of Chiapas.

They have accused Mr Escandon of not doing enough to help their rural community and have demanded more public resources, including the building of a promised road.

Farmers are angry at a lack of resources for their community and have demanded a promised road be built (CEN)

The mayor was pushed outside, tied with rope to the back of a vehicle and dragged for several dozen metres down the street.

Police and council workers intervened and managed to free him.

Mayor Escandon, who was unhurt in the incident, said afterwards his attackers wanted to extort money from him.

He said: ‘Around 50 or 60 people came in three pickup trucks, armed with clubs and looking to kidnap city officials to extort us and get what they’ve always wanted: to be given money.

‘They started struggling, carrying me, tied up one foot and dragged me out of my office to the street.’

Mayor Jorge Luis Escandon was not injured in the attack (Picture: CEN)

This is not the first time that farmers from Santa Rita El Invernadero have staged a violent protest (Picture: CEN)

Eleven people were arrested and a dozen injured in the melee.

The town hall was also damaged and the National Guard have been patrolling the town of 20,000 people near Mexico’s border with Guatemala.

State prosecutor Jorge Luis Llaven said the attackers were demanding more public resources, including direct cash transfers, for their rural community, Santa Rita El Invernadero.

Leftist Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador has introduced a policy of giving cash directly to beneficiaries to cut out bureaucratic middlemen in order to stem corruption.

This is not the first time that farmers from Santa Rita El Invernadero have staged a violent protest.

Four months ago they vandalised the town hall, demanding that Mr Escandon fulfil promises he had made during the 2018 election campaign.
